comment.author: 67800098@N07
comment._content: Wonderful Collection, really enjoyed the ride back in time when the world was a different place... Thank You.

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: This may be Ron Cazey on his Blackbird bicycle, built by Don Blackman, in Ashfield, N.S.W. www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=362418 It seems to have a B.S.A. chainwheel, as did most Australian handbuilt racing cycles of that period?

comment.author: 14343849@N05
comment._content:
Nice! 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] How can you tell it might be handbuilt? I'd like to know.

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vercettisworld] It's just possible to read 'Blackbird' on the down-tube, and according to the link, they were built by Don Blackman, maybe exclusively for Ron Cazey? B.S.A. would supply lugs & Reynolds tubing (531 in this case), to builders such as Malvern Star in Melbourne, Bastide in Paris, & De Mol in Holland (and probably many others?).

comment.author: 14343849@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia]  Good detective work! Was the tubing all straight-gauge back then?

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/vercettisworld] Reynolds first developed butted tubing in around 1900, but I don't think 531 tubing was butted when introduced in 1935?
This photo looks to be closer to 1940, so I think it might just be built with butted tubing?

comment.author: 14343849@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia]  Aha! But when did double-butted tubing come into the mainstream? I remember my bike-racing friends going nuts over it in the 1980's. Then came carbon-fiber, in both bikes AND skies and they began confusing me!
